title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: Does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
Responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning concerning the most significant economic cause of the outbreak of the French Revolution.

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.
descriptions: Does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the prompt.

Describes a broader historical context relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

title: PART C: EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml: To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn two points, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.
descriptions: Does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

Provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

Supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence. The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration: Examples of evidence used might include:

  • Inequality/inefficiency of French taxation system under the monarchy

  • Internal tariffs and trade barriers in Old Regime France

  • Costs of French foreign policy, especially intervention in the American Revolution

  • Growing importance of financial and mercantile sectors of French economy

  • Food shortages and famines in the late 1700s caused by bad weather and poor agricultural techniques

title: PART D: ANALYSIS AND REASONING
stimulusHtml: To earn the first point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.
descriptions: Does not use historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, CCOT) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.
Uses historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, CCOT) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.
